A group is a monoid $G$ such that every element of $G$ admits an inverse. More explicitly, this means we are given a set $G$ with a law of composition $G \times G \longrightarrow G,(a, b) \longmapsto a b$, such that: (i) The law is associative, i.e., we have $(a b) c=a(b c)$ for $a, b, c \in G$. (ii) There exists $a$ unit element, i.e., an element $e \in$ such that $e a=a=a e$ for all $a \in G$. (iii) Every element $a \in G$ admits an inverse, i.e., an element $b \in G$ such that $a b=e=b a$. The group is called commutative or abelian if the law is commutative, i.e., if (iv) $a b=b a$ for all $a, b \in G$.
Let $G$ be a group and $S \subset G$ a subset. The centralizer of $S$ in $G$ is given by $Z_{S}=\{x \in G ; x s=s x \text { for all } s \in S\} .$
Does the concept of a/an Group need to be defined for a definition of a/an Centralizer to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a Centralizer inherently relies on the concept of a group. According to the provided definition, the Centralizer of a subset $S$ in a group $G$ is defined as $Z_{S} = \{x \in G ; x s = s x \text{ for all } s \in S\}$. This definition presupposes the existence of a group $G$ because it involves elements $x$ and $s$ that are part of $G$, and it uses the group operation (the product $xs$ and $sx$). Without the concept of a group, the operations and the very set $G$ from which $x$ and $s$ are chosen would not be defined. Therefore, the concept of a group is essential for the definition of a Centralizer to make sense, as it provides the structural and operational framework necessary for defining what it means for elements to 'centralize' a subset within that structure.
